sn26.4:1.5.eng: is the manifestation of old age and death.

sn26.4:1.6.pli: Yo ca kho, bhikkhave, cakkhusamphassassa nirodho …pe…

sn26.4:1.9.eng: is the disappearance of old age and death.”

sn26.5:1.2.pli: “Yo kho, bhikkhave, cakkhusamphassajāya vedanāya uppādo ṭhiti …pe… jarāmaraṇassa pātubhāvo …pe….
sn26.5:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, the arising of feeling born of eye contact …

sn26.5:2.1.eng: the arising of feeling born of mind contact …

sn26.5:2.2.eng: is the manifestation of old age and death.

sn26.5:2.3.pli: Yo ca kho, bhikkhave, cakkhusamphassajāya vedanāya nirodho vūpasamo …pe…
sn26.5:2.3.eng: The cessation of feeling born of eye contact …

sn26.5:2.5.pli: yo manosamphassajāya vedanāya nirodho vūpasamo atthaṅgamo, dukkhasseso nirodho, rogānaṃ vūpasamo, jarāmaraṇassa atthaṅgamo”ti.
sn26.5:2.5.eng: the cessation of feeling born of mind contact … is the disappearance of old age and death.”

sn26.6:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, the arising of perception of sights …

sn26.6:1.4.pli: yo dhammasaññāya uppādo ṭhiti abhinibbatti pātubhāvo, dukkhasseso uppādo, rogānaṃ ṭhiti, jarāmaraṇassa pātubhāvo.
sn26.6:1.4.eng: perception of ideas … is the manifestation of old age and death.

sn26.6:1.5.pli: Yo ca kho, bhikkhave, rūpasaññāya nirodho …pe…
sn26.6:1.5.eng: The cessation of perception of sights …

sn26.6:1.7.pli: yo dhammasaññāya nirodho vūpasamo atthaṅgamo, dukkhasseso nirodho, rogānaṃ vūpasamo, jarāmaraṇassa atthaṅgamo”ti.
sn26.6:1.7.eng: perception of ideas … is the disappearance of old age and death.”

sn26.7:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, the arising of intentions regarding sights …

sn26.7:1.4.pli: yo dhammasañcetanāya uppādo ṭhiti abhinibbatti pātubhāvo, dukkhasseso uppādo, rogānaṃ ṭhiti, jarāmaraṇassa pātubhāvo.
sn26.7:1.4.eng: intentions regarding ideas … is the manifestation of old age and death.

sn26.7:1.5.pli: Yo ca kho, bhikkhave, rūpasañcetanāya nirodho …pe…
sn26.7:1.5.eng: The cessation of intentions regarding sights …

sn26.7:1.7.pli: yo dhammasañcetanāya nirodho vūpasamo atthaṅgamo, dukkhasseso nirodho, rogānaṃ vūpasamo, jarāmaraṇassa atthaṅgamo”ti.
sn26.7:1.7.eng: intentions regarding ideas … is the disappearance of old age and death.”

sn26.8:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, the arising of craving for sights …

sn26.8:1.4.pli: yo dhammataṇhāya uppādo ṭhiti abhinibbatti pātubhāvo, dukkhasseso uppādo, rogānaṃ ṭhiti, jarāmaraṇassa pātubhāvo.
sn26.8:1.4.eng: craving for ideas … is the manifestation of old age and death.

sn26.8:1.5.pli: Yo ca kho, bhikkhave, rūpataṇhāya nirodho …pe…
sn26.8:1.5.eng: The cessation of craving for sights …

sn26.8:1.7.pli: yo dhammataṇhāya nirodho vūpasamo atthaṅgamo, dukkhasseso nirodho, rogānaṃ vūpasamo, jarāmaraṇassa atthaṅgamo”ti.
sn26.8:1.7.eng: craving for ideas … is the disappearance of old age and death.”

sn26.9:1.2.pli: “Yo kho, bhikkhave, pathavīdhātuyā uppādo ṭhiti abhinibbatti pātubhāvo …pe… jarāmaraṇassa pātubhāvo;
sn26.9:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, the arising, continuation, and manifestation and regeneration of the earth element,

sn26.9:1.6.comm: The inclusion of the space and consciousness elements distinguish this from SN 14.36.

sn26.9:1.7.pli: yo viññāṇadhātuyā uppādo ṭhiti abhinibbatti pātubhāvo, dukkhasseso uppādo, rogānaṃ ṭhiti, jarāmaraṇassa pātubhāvo.
sn26.9:1.7.eng: and the consciousness element is the arising of suffering, the continuation of diseases, and the manifestation of old age and death.

sn26.9:1.8.pli: Yo ca kho, bhikkhave, pathavīdhātuyā nirodho …pe… jarāmaraṇassa atthaṅgamo;
sn26.9:1.8.eng: The cessation of the earth element,

sn26.9:1.13.pli: yo viññāṇadhātuyā nirodho vūpasamo atthaṅgamo, dukkhasseso nirodho, rogānaṃ vūpasamo, jarāmaraṇassa atthaṅgamo”ti.
sn26.9:1.13.eng: and the consciousness element is the cessation of suffering, the settling of diseases, and the disappearance of old age and death.”

sn27.1:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, desire and greed for the eye,

sn27.1:1.7.eng: or mind is a corruption of the mind.

sn27.1:1.8.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno imesu chasu ṭhānesu cetaso upakkileso pahīno hoti, nekkhammaninnañcassa cittaṃ hoti.
sn27.1:1.8.eng: When a mendicant has given up mental corruption in these six cases, their mind inclines to renunciation.

sn27.1:1.9.pli: Nekkhammaparibhāvitaṃ cittaṃ kammaniyaṃ khāyati, abhiññā sacchikaraṇīyesu dhammesū”ti.
sn27.1:1.9.eng: A mind imbued with renunciation is said to be fit for work regarding anything that can be realized by insight.”
sn27.1:1.9.comm: I take khāyati as the passive “is said to be”, like the more common akkhāyati (SN 22.102:5). | Kammaniya (“fit for work, workable”) is similar in sense to bhabba (“capable”) at eg. MN 119:29.1.

sn27.10:1.2.pli: “Yo, bhikkhave, rūpasmiṃ chandarāgo, cittasseso upakkileso …pe… yo viññāṇasmiṃ chandarāgo, cittasseso upakkileso.
sn27.10:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, desire and greed for form, feeling, perception, choices, or consciousness is a corruption of the mind.

sn27.10:1.3.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno imesu pañcasu ṭhānesu cetaso upakkileso pahīno hoti, nekkhammaninnañcassa cittaṃ hoti.
sn27.10:1.3.eng: When a mendicant has given up mental corruption in these five cases, their mind inclines to renunciation.

sn27.10:1.4.pli: Nekkhammaparibhāvitaṃ cittaṃ kammaniyaṃ khāyati, abhiññā sacchikaraṇīyesu dhammesū”ti.
sn27.10:1.4.eng: A mind imbued with renunciation is said to be fit for work regarding anything that can be realized by insight.”

sn27.10:2.5.eng: The Linked Discourses on corruptions are complete.

sn27.2:1.7.eng: or ideas is a corruption of the mind.

sn27.2:1.8.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno imesu chasu ṭhānesu cetaso upakkileso pahīno hoti, nekkhammaninnañcassa cittaṃ hoti.
sn27.2:1.8.eng: When a mendicant has given up mental corruption in these six cases, their mind inclines to renunciation.

sn27.2:1.9.pli: Nekkhammaparibhāvitaṃ cittaṃ kammaniyaṃ khāyati, abhiññā sacchikaraṇīyesu dhammesū”ti.
sn27.2:1.9.eng: A mind imbued with renunciation is said to be fit for work regarding anything that can be realized by insight.”

sn27.3:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, desire and greed for eye consciousness,

sn27.3:1.7.eng: or mind consciousness is a corruption of the mind.

sn27.3:1.8.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno imesu chasu ṭhānesu cetaso upakkileso pahīno hoti, nekkhammaninnañcassa cittaṃ hoti.
sn27.3:1.8.eng: When a mendicant has given up mental corruption in these six cases, their mind inclines to renunciation.

sn27.3:1.9.pli: Nekkhammaparibhāvitaṃ cittaṃ kammaniyaṃ khāyati, abhiññā sacchikaraṇīyesu dhammesū”ti.
sn27.3:1.9.eng: A mind imbued with renunciation is said to be fit for work regarding anything that can be realized by insight.”

sn27.4:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, desire and greed for eye contact,

sn27.4:1.7.eng: or mind contact is a corruption of the mind. …”

sn27.5:1.2.pli: “Yo, bhikkhave, cakkhusamphassajāya vedanāya chandarāgo, cittasseso upakkileso.
sn27.5:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, desire and greed for feeling born of eye contact,

sn27.5:1.7.pli: yo manosamphassajāya vedanāya chandarāgo, cittasseso upakkileso.
sn27.5:1.7.eng: or feeling born of mind contact is a defilement of the mind. …”

sn27.6:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, desire and greed for perception of sights,

sn27.6:1.7.eng: or perception of ideas is a corruption of the mind. …”

sn27.7:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, desire and greed for intention regarding sights,

sn27.7:1.7.eng: or intention regarding ideas is a corruption of the mind. …”

sn27.8:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, desire and greed for craving for sights,

sn27.8:1.7.eng: or craving for ideas is a corruption of the mind. …”

sn27.9:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, desire and greed for the earth element,

sn27.9:1.7.eng: or the consciousness element is a corruption of the mind. …”

sn27.9:1.8.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno imesu chasu ṭhānesu cetaso upakkileso pahīno hoti, nekkhammaninnañcassa cittaṃ hoti.

sn27.9:1.9.pli: Nekkhammaparibhāvitaṃ cittaṃ kammaniyaṃ khāyati, abhiññā sacchikaraṇīyesu dhammesū”ti.

sn28.1:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā sāriputto sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
sn28.1:1.1.eng: At one time Venerable Sāriputta was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
sn28.1:1.1.comm: Sāriputta, personal name Upatissa (MN 24:17.3), was the foremost in wisdom (AN 1.189), the “general of the Dhamma” (Ud 2.8:16.2) who was like unto the Teacher himself (MN 24:17.5, Snp 3.7:22.4, MN 111:22.2). He was known for his magnificent expositions of fundamental teachings (MN 9, MN 141), his ready conversation on profound matters (MN 24, MN 43), his guidance for fellow monastics (MN 5), his humility (Kd 16:6.1.4), his expertise in meditation (AN 7.41) even to the deepest levels (AN 11.21:1.2), his consolation of those in distress (MN 97:27.1, MN 143, MN 144:3.2), and his personal qualities of gentleness and forgiveness (AN 9.11). His verses are at Thag 17.2. He went forth together with his great friend Moggallāna (Kd 1:23.1.1; see note on MN 74:1.2). Together they were hailed as the Buddha’s “chief disciples” (SN 15.20:5.7). They were leaders of the Saṅgha under the Buddha (MN 67:13.7), entrusted with serious disciplinary matters (Bu Ss 13:1.6.24). Although they were heirs apparent to the Buddha (Kd 17:3.1.12), they both predeceased him (SN 47.14:2.4). | Tradition holds that his mother was named Rūpasārī, his father the brahmin Vaṅganta, and that his younger siblings—Cunda, Upasena, Revata, Cālā, Upacālā, and Sisūpacālā—all joined the Saṅgha.

sn28.1:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sāvatthiṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
sn28.1:1.2.eng: Then Venerable Sāriputta robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms.

sn28.1:1.3.pli: Sāvatthiyaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto yena andhavanaṃ tenupasaṅkami divāvihārāya.
sn28.1:1.3.eng: He wandered for alms in Sāvatthī. After the meal, on his return from almsround, he went to the Dark Forest for the day’s meditation,

sn28.1:1.4.pli: Andhavanaṃ ajjhogāhetvā aññatarasmiṃ rukkhamūle divāvihāraṃ nisīdi.
sn28.1:1.4.eng: plunged deep into it, and sat at the root of a tree to meditate.

sn28.1:2.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yena jetavanaṃ anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāmo tenupasaṅkami.
sn28.1:2.1.eng: Then in the late afternoon, Sāriputta came out of retreat and went to Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

sn28.1:2.2.pli: Addasā kho āyasmā ānando āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ.
sn28.1:2.2.eng: Venerable Ānanda saw him coming off in the distance,

sn28.1:2.4.pli: “vippasannāni kho te, āvuso sāriputta, indriyāni; parisuddho mukhavaṇṇo pariyodāto.
sn28.1:2.4.eng: “Reverend Sāriputta, your faculties are so very clear, and your complexion is pure and bright.
sn28.1:2.4.comm: Here “faculties” refers to visible features such as bright eyes. Compare Chāndogya Upaniṣad 4.14.2, where a students face is seen as bright and glowing due to their recent insights.

sn28.1:2.5.eng: What meditation were you practicing today?”

sn28.1:3.1.pli: “Idhāhaṃ, āvuso, vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharāmi.
sn28.1:3.1.eng: “Reverend, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, I entered and remained in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

sn28.1:3.2.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, āvuso, na evaṃ hoti:
sn28.1:3.2.eng: But it didn’t occur to me:

sn28.1:3.3.pli: ‘ahaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ samāpajjāmī’ti vā ‘ahaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ samāpanno’ti vā ‘ahaṃ paṭhamā jhānā vuṭṭhito’ti vā”ti.
sn28.1:3.3.eng: ‘I am entering the first absorption’ or ‘I have entered the first absorption’ or ‘I am emerging from the first absorption’.”

sn28.1:3.4.pli: Tathā hi panāyasmato sāriputtassa dīgharattaṃ ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānānusayā susamūhatā.
sn28.1:3.4.eng: “That must be because Venerable Sāriputta has long ago totally eradicated I-making, mine-making, and the underlying tendency to conceit.

sn28.1:3.5.pli: Tasmā āyasmato sāriputtassa na evaṃ hoti:
sn28.1:3.5.eng: That’s why it didn’t occur to you:

sn28.1:3.6.pli: “‘ahaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ samāpajjāmī’ti vā ‘ahaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ samāpanno’ti vā ‘ahaṃ paṭhamā jhānā vuṭṭhito’ti vā”ti.
sn28.1:3.6.eng: ‘I am entering the first absorption’ or ‘I have entered the first absorption’ or ‘I am emerging from the first absorption’.”

sn28.10:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā sāriputto rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
sn28.10:1.1.eng: At one time Venerable Sāriputta was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

sn28.10:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya rājagahe piṇḍāya pāvisi.
sn28.10:1.2.eng: Then he robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Rājagaha for alms.

sn28.10:1.3.pli: Rājagahe sapadānaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā taṃ piṇḍapātaṃ aññataraṃ kuṭṭamūlaṃ nissāya paribhuñjati.
sn28.10:1.3.eng: After wandering indiscriminately for almsfood in Rājagaha, he ate his almsfood by a wall.

sn28.10:1.4.pli: Atha kho sucimukhī paribbājikā yenāyasmā sāriputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ etadavoca:
sn28.10:1.4.eng: Then the wanderer Sucimukhī went up to Venerable Sāriputta and said to him:
sn28.10:1.4.comm: We don’t meet Sucimukhī elsewhere. Her name appears to mean “fair-face”, but it may be a misspelling of sūcimukhī, “needle-mouth”, used elsewhere of mosquitoes or similar creatures (MN 130:20.3, Atharva Veda 11.10.3). Bold women were a feature of the ascetic communities, as shown by Bhaddā of the Curly Hair (Thig 5.9) or Gārgī Vācaknavī (Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 3.6.1). Perhaps Sucimukhī was known for poking people with annoying questions.

sn28.10:2.1.comm: To “eat” (bhuñjati) is is both to “enjoy” and to “nourish”. Her question is deliberately obscure, a test for the supposedly wise Sāriputta, but from the context it’s clear she is asking about right livelihood. The brahmins made sure that they worshiped the god the right way, so as to ensure the bounty of spiritual blessings, monetary fees, and food. | At Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 10.5.5 we find a similar challenge and response. When a certain Kuśri Vājaśravasa built a fire altar, he was quizzed by Suśruvas Kauṣya whether he built it with Agni’s face forward (east), backward (west), downward (south) or upwards (north). Suśruvas faults all these methods; for example, in some cases it is like giving food to someone facing the wrong way. Kuśri responds that he has built it in all these ways, for which he supplies symbolic rationales. Sucimukhī may be echoing this very dialogue, or at least, engaging in a similar manner of questioning.

sn28.10:2.3.eng: “Well then, do you eat facing upwards?”

sn28.10:2.5.eng: “Well then, do you eat facing the cardinal directions?”

sn28.10:2.7.eng: “Well then, do you eat facing the intermediate directions?”

sn28.10:3.1.pli: “‘Kiṃ nu, samaṇa, adhomukho bhuñjasī’ti iti puṭṭho samāno ‘na khvāhaṃ, bhagini, adhomukho bhuñjāmī’ti vadesi.
sn28.10:3.1.eng: “When asked if you eat facing all these directions, you answer ‘no, sister’.

sn28.10:3.2.pli: ‘Tena hi, samaṇa, ubbhamukho bhuñjasī’ti iti puṭṭho samāno ‘na khvāhaṃ, bhagini, ubbhamukho bhuñjāmī’ti vadesi.

sn28.10:3.3.pli: ‘Tena hi, samaṇa, disāmukho bhuñjasī’ti iti puṭṭho samāno ‘na khvāhaṃ, bhagini, disāmukho bhuñjāmī’ti vadesi.

sn28.10:3.4.pli: ‘Tena hi, samaṇa, vidisāmukho bhuñjasī’ti iti puṭṭho samāno ‘na khvāhaṃ, bhagini, vidisāmukho bhuñjāmī’ti vadesi.

sn28.10:4.1.eng: How then do you eat, ascetic?”

sn28.10:4.2.pli: “Ye hi keci, bhagini, samaṇabrāhmaṇā vatthuvijjātiracchānavijjāya micchājīvena jīvikaṃ kappenti, ime vuccanti, bhagini, samaṇabrāhmaṇā ‘adhomukhā bhuñjantī’ti.
sn28.10:4.2.eng: “Sister, those ascetics and brahmins who earn a living by geomancy—a low lore, a wrong livelihood—are said to eat facing downwards.
sn28.10:4.2.comm: Where Kuśri responds with obscure allusions to symbolic connections of the ritual, Sāriputta answers the riddle in a way that is simultaneously literal and meaningful. He doesn’t try to out-riddle the riddler, but identifies the ethical responsibility of taking almsfood. | For “geomancy” (vatthuvijjā) see DN 1:1.21.2. Varāhamihira details it at Bṛhatsaṁhitā 52, where it involves a detailed architectural plan so a building accords with the divinities and auguries of the place.

sn28.10:4.3.pli: Ye hi keci, bhagini, samaṇabrāhmaṇā nakkhattavijjātiracchānavijjāya micchājīvena jīvikaṃ kappenti, ime vuccanti, bhagini, samaṇabrāhmaṇā ‘ubbhamukhā bhuñjantī’ti.
sn28.10:4.3.eng: Those ascetics and brahmins who earn a living by astrology—a low lore, a wrong livelihood—are said to eat facing upwards.
sn28.10:4.3.comm: The technical term “astrology” (nakkhattavijjā) is only found here, but it is described at DN 1:1.24.2. Indian astrology is a vast and complex field, intertwined with the origins of mathematics.

sn28.10:4.4.pli: Ye hi keci, bhagini, samaṇabrāhmaṇā dūteyyapahiṇagamanānuyogāya micchājīvena jīvikaṃ kappenti, ime vuccanti, bhagini, samaṇabrāhmaṇā ‘disāmukhā bhuñjantī’ti.
sn28.10:4.4.eng: Those ascetics and brahmins who earn a living by running errands and messages—a wrong livelihood—are said to eat facing the cardinal directions.
sn28.10:4.4.comm: Described at DN 1:1.19.1. Acting as a go-between for lay business was tempting due to the mendicants’ wandering lifestyle. However, it exposes them to risk if the message is not delivered or if it is bad news.

sn28.10:4.5.pli: Ye hi keci, bhagini, samaṇabrāhmaṇā aṅgavijjātiracchānavijjāya micchājīvena jīvikaṃ kappenti, ime vuccanti, bhagini, samaṇabrāhmaṇā ‘vidisāmukhā bhuñjantī’ti.
sn28.10:4.5.eng: Those ascetics and brahmins who earn a living by limb-reading—a low lore, a wrong livelihood—are said to eat facing the intermediate directions.
sn28.10:4.5.comm: Bṛhatsaṁhitā 50 details the lore of angavidyā, “limb-reading”. This involves a close study of a person’s physical features and behaviors.

sn28.10:5.1.pli: So khvāhaṃ, bhagini, na vatthuvijjātiracchānavijjāya micchājīvena jīvikaṃ kappemi, na nakkhattavijjātiracchānavijjāya micchājīvena jīvikaṃ kappemi, na dūteyyapahiṇagamanānuyogāya micchājīvena jīvikaṃ kappemi, na aṅgavijjātiracchānavijjāya micchājīvena jīvikaṃ kappemi.
sn28.10:5.1.eng: I don’t earn a living by any of these means.

sn28.10:5.2.eng: I seek alms in a principled manner,

sn28.10:5.3.eng: and I eat it in a principled manner.”

sn28.10:6.1.pli: Atha kho sucimukhī paribbājikā rājagahe rathiyāya rathiyaṃ, siṅghāṭakena siṅghāṭakaṃ upasaṅkamitvā evamārocesi:
sn28.10:6.1.eng: Then Sucimukhī the wanderer went around Rājagaha from street to street and from square to square, and announced:

sn28.10:6.2.eng: “The ascetics who follow the Sakyan eat food in a principled manner!

sn28.10:6.3.eng: The ascetics who follow the Sakyan eat food blamelessly!

sn28.10:6.4.eng: Give almsfood to the ascetics who follow the Sakyan!”

sn28.10:7.7.eng: The Linked Discourses on Sāriputta are complete.

sn28.2:1.2.pli: Addasā kho āyasmā ānando …pe… āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ etadavoca:
sn28.2:1.2.eng: Venerable Ānanda saw Venerable Sāriputta and said to him:

sn28.2:1.3.pli: “vippasannāni kho te, āvuso sāriputta, indriyāni; parisuddho mukhavaṇṇo pariyodāto.
sn28.2:1.3.eng: “Reverend Sāriputta, your faculties are so very clear, and your complexion is pure and bright.

sn28.2:1.4.eng: What meditation were you practicing today?”

sn28.2:2.1.pli: “Idhāhaṃ, āvuso, vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ samādhijaṃ pītisukhaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharāmi.
sn28.2:2.1.eng: “Reverend, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected were stilled, I entered and remained in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.

sn28.2:2.2.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, āvuso, na evaṃ hoti:
sn28.2:2.2.eng: But it didn’t occur to me:

sn28.2:2.3.pli: ‘ahaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ samāpajjāmī’ti vā ‘ahaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ samāpanno’ti vā ‘ahaṃ dutiyā jhānā vuṭṭhito’ti vā”ti.
sn28.2:2.3.eng: ‘I am entering the second absorption’ or ‘I have entered the second absorption’ or ‘I am emerging from the second absorption’.”

sn28.2:2.4.pli: Tathā hi panāyasmato sāriputtassa dīgharattaṃ ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānānusayā susamūhatā.
sn28.2:2.4.eng: “That must be because Venerable Sāriputta has long ago totally eradicated I-making, mine-making, and the underlying tendency to conceit.

sn28.2:2.5.pli: Tasmā āyasmato sāriputtassa na evaṃ hoti:
sn28.2:2.5.eng: That’s why it didn’t occur to you:

sn28.2:2.6.pli: “‘ahaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ samāpajjāmī’ti vā ‘ahaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ samāpanno’ti vā ‘ahaṃ dutiyā jhānā vuṭṭhito’ti vā”ti.
sn28.2:2.6.eng: ‘I am entering the second absorption’ or ‘I have entered the second absorption’ or ‘I am emerging from the second absorption’.”

sn28.3:1.2.eng: Venerable Ānanda saw Venerable Sāriputta and said to him:

sn28.3:1.3.pli: “vippasannāni kho te, āvuso sāriputta, indriyāni; parisuddho mukhavaṇṇo pariyodāto.
sn28.3:1.3.eng: “Reverend Sāriputta, your faculties are so very clear, and your complexion is pure and bright.

sn28.3:1.4.eng: What meditation were you practicing today?”

sn28.3:2.1.pli: “Idhāhaṃ, āvuso, pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca vihāsiṃ sato ca sampajāno sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṃvedemi; yaṃ taṃ ariyā ācikkhanti ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharāmi.
sn28.3:2.1.eng: “Reverend, with the fading away of rapture, I entered and remained in the third absorption, where I meditated with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’

sn28.3:2.2.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, āvuso, na evaṃ hoti:
sn28.3:2.2.eng: But it didn’t occur to me:

sn28.3:2.3.pli: ‘ahaṃ tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ samāpajjāmī’ti vā ‘ahaṃ tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ samāpanno’ti vā ‘ahaṃ tatiyā jhānā vuṭṭhito’ti vā”ti.
sn28.3:2.3.eng: ‘I am entering the third absorption’ or ‘I have entered the third absorption’ or ‘I am emerging from the third absorption’.”

sn28.3:2.4.pli: Tathā hi panāyasmato sāriputtassa dīgharattaṃ ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānānusayā susamūhatā.
sn28.3:2.4.eng: “That must be because Venerable Sāriputta has long ago totally eradicated I-making, mine-making, and the underlying tendency to conceit.

sn28.3:2.5.pli: Tasmā āyasmato sāriputtassa na evaṃ hoti:
sn28.3:2.5.eng: That’s why it didn’t occur to you:

sn28.3:2.6.pli: “‘ahaṃ tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ samāpajjāmī’ti vā ‘ahaṃ tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ samāpanno’ti vā ‘ahaṃ tatiyā jhānā vuṭṭhito’ti vā”ti.
sn28.3:2.6.eng: ‘I am entering the third absorption’ or ‘I have entered the third absorption’ or ‘I am emerging from the third absorption’.”
